title: Borussia Dortmund fans condemn RB Leipzig violence as side need penalties to see off Hertha Berlin in German Cup
text:
Borussia Dortmund fans condemn RB Leipzig violence as side need penalties to see off Hertha Berlin in German Cup Supporters held up banners apologising to RBL fans after attacks occurred outside the Westfalenstadion last weekend Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Borussia Dortmund fans held up banners stating "no to violence" and apologising to RB Leipzig during their German Cup win over Hertha Berlin. 
The weekend clash with the Red Bull-backed club was marred by fan violence outside the ground, while the ‘Yellow Wall’ banner show against RBL has been labelled in some quarters as a “wall of hate”. 
On Tuesday, Dortmund offered an apology and “strongly condemned” the violence seen outside the Westfalenstadion, after away supporters were pelted with stones and cans by home fans, leading to injuries amongst the travelling contingent. Four police officers and a police dog were also injured. (Photo: REUTERS) "Against violence" (Photo: AFP/Getty Images) 
In all, Dortmund police have filed 28 charges for breaches of the law, including assault, dangerous bodily harm, damage to property and theft, as well as regarding explosives and in the lead up to the game, BVB boss Thomas Tuchel was heavily critical of the incidents. 
"A line was massively crossed by our fans and we condemn it," the German coach declared. 
Club captain Marcel Schmelzer had echoed his manager's sentiments ahead of Wednesday night's game, telling supporters in a video message: "We players were and are horrified and sat at what happened. Saturday night, people were harmed and we condemn this as a team." 
Ahead of the last-16 meeting with Hertha, fans held up signs declaring themselves "against rampage" and violence. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
